%text The $m-$th term \underline\text{from the end $(m\geq 1)$} is the $(n-m+2)-$th term \underline\text{from the} \underline\text{beginning}, as can be seen from the expansion below
\[ (a+b)^n = \overbrace{T_1 + T_2 + \ldots + \underbrace{T_k + \ldots + T_{n+1}}_{m\text{ terms}}}^{n+1 \text{ terms}} \]
%
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{From the end }$(m)$ & \text{From the beginning } $(k)$ \\ \hline 1 & n-1+2 = n+1 \\ \hline n & n-n+2 = 2 \\ \hline n+1 & n-(n+1) + 2 = 1 \\ \hline \end{tabular} %text
\underline\text{Middle Terms} Similar to finding the $m-$th term from the end is the idea of finding the middle terms in an expansion. Note that $k$ is the position of the middle terms \underline\text{from the beginning}.
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline n & n+ 1\text{ terms} & \text{Middle Term(s)} = k \\ \hline \text{Even} & \text{Odd} & \left( \frac{n}{2}+1\right) \\ \hline \text{Odd} & \text{Even} & \left( \frac{n+1}{2}\right) \text{ and }\left(\frac{n+3}{2}\right) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
